user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_QueueGetInfo:
```c
int32 OS_QueueGetInfo(osal_id_t queue_id, OS_queue_prop_t *queue_prop)
{
    OS_common_record_t *record;
    int32               return_code;
    OS_object_token_t   token;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(queue_prop);

    memset(queue_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_queue_prop_t));

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, queue_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        record = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_global_queue_table, token);

        strncpy(queue_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(queue_prop->name) - 1);
        queue_prop->creator = record->creator;

        /*
         * Currently there are no additional queue details provided by the impl layer -
         * But this could be added in the future (i.e. current/max depth, msg size, etc)
         */

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_QueueGetInfo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
extern OS_common_record_t *const OS_global_queue_table
...
typedef struct
{
    char      name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t creator;
} OS_queue_prop_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
int32 OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_lock_mode_t lock_mode, osal_objtype_t idtype, osal_id_t id, OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int32 return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit(lock_mode, idtype, token);
    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return return_code;
    }

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex(idtype, id, &token->obj_idx);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        token->obj_id = id;

        /*
         * The "ConvertToken" routine will return with the global lock
         * in a state appropriate for returning to the caller, as indicated
         * by the "check_mode" parameter.
         *
         * Note If this operation fails, then it always unlocks the global for
         * all check_mode's other than NONE.
         */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdConvertToken(token);
    }

    if (return_code != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel(token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
...
void OS_ObjectIdRelease(OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_ObjectIdTransactionFinish(token, NULL);
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I examined all uses of the function parameter queue_prop in OS_QueueGetInfo. The following uses were considered and are not suspicious under MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8: - OS_CHECK_POINTER(queue_prop) — only checks pointer is non-NULL (no modification of the pointer variable itself). - memset(queue_prop, 0, sizeof(OS_queue_prop_t)) — modifies the object pointed to by queue_prop (allowed; the rule permits modifying the object referred to by a pointer parameter). - strncpy(queue_prop->name, record->name_entry, sizeof(queue_prop->name) - 1) — modifies the pointed-to object (allowed). - queue_prop->creator = record->creator — modifies a member of the pointed-to object (allowed). - use of sizeof(queue_prop->name) and other read accesses — do not modify the pointer itself. There are no assignments to the parameter variable queue_prop (e.g., queue_prop = ...), no pointer arithmetic that alters queue_prop, and no calls that receive queue_prop by address to reassign it. Therefore there are no fragments in this function that violate Rule 17.8 and nothing needs to be investigated further for this rule.
